hypothesis: Mobile platforms (iOS and Android combined) experience disproportionate checkout flow issues, reducing their conversion rates and pulling down overall platform performance
causal_history: Mobile checkout experiences are often more fragile due to screen size constraints and interaction differences. If the new checkout flow released on December 16th has platform-specific rendering issues, timeout problems, or touch-interaction bugs that primarily affect mobile users, their conversion rates would decline sharply. During the holiday shopping season, mobile often represents a significant share of traffic, so a mobile-specific checkout issue could cause a notable overall conversion rate decline starting December 17th.
summary_of_analysis_performed: Iteration 1: Compared overall conversion rates by device type (web, iOS, Android) for baseline vs anomaly periods. Found web flat (+0.03%), iOS severely down (-55.51%), Android moderately down (-10.37%). Iteration 2: Detailed breakdown with absolute numbers showed iOS lost 1,026 orders despite gaining 8,338 sessions, indicating a severe per-session conversion collapse. Android showed more modest decline. Iteration 3: Daily trend analysis showed iOS consistently underperforming web on every single day (Dec 17-24), with zero exceptions. Pattern is stable at 2.17% daily avg vs web 5.38% avg. Iteration 4: Cross-dimensional analysis confirmed mobile impact is NOT category or user-type specific—iOS consistently dropped -55% across all 4 product categories and both new/returning user types, strongly suggesting a platform-level issue rather than category-specific problem.

findings.finding: iOS conversion rate collapsed by 55.51% while Web remained flat at +0.03%
findings.evidence: iOS baseline CR: 4.89%, anomaly CR: 2.17% (-2.71 pp); Web baseline CR: 5.38%, anomaly CR: 5.38% (+0.00 pp)

findings.finding: iOS was 5.4x more severely impacted than Android; both mobile platforms under-performed Web
findings.evidence: iOS change: -55.51%; Android change: -10.37%; Web change: +0.03%. Mobile combined: -38.49%

findings.finding: iOS underperformed Web on 8 out of 8 days during anomaly period, showing consistent daily pattern
findings.evidence: iOS daily CR: 2.07-2.23% (avg 2.17%) vs Web daily CR: 5.26-5.57% (avg 5.38%) throughout Dec 17-24

findings.finding: Mobile conversion degradation is NOT category-specific; iOS impacted uniformly across all product categories
findings.evidence: Electronics: -55.5%, Fashion: -54.6%, Home: -56.3%, Groceries: -55.6% (iOS impact consistent across all 4 categories)

findings.finding: Mobile conversion degradation affects both new and returning users equally, suggesting platform-level issue
findings.evidence: iOS new users: -55.2%; iOS returning users: -55.5% (nearly identical impact across user types)

findings.finding: Absolute order volume loss: iOS lost approximately 1,026 fewer orders despite 8,338 additional sessions
findings.evidence: iOS baseline: 2,175 orders from 44,502 sessions; Anomaly: 1,149 orders from 52,840 sessions
